Award.AwardTitle: DMSS: a Dark Matter Summer School
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for DMSS (Dark Matter Summer School), a summer school dedicated only to dark matter. The school is geared towards junior graduate students and will have a few spots open for exceptional undergraduate students. The summer school will be held at the University at Albany, SUNY. It is foreseen to be held from July 16-20, 2018.

The summer school will impact the community on three levels: minority students, high school students and the general public. Women and underrepresented minority students will be given a place of choice, at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. The organizers will promote diversity and encourage underrepresented minorities to pursue their studies in graduate schools by reaching out to women-only colleges, as well as historically black colleges and universities. DMSS will also contain an outreach component, allowing select high school students, at least one from an inner city high school, to come, take a tour of a research lab, attend student's talks, and discuss with both undergraduate, graduate students and lecturers to give them an idea of what a future in physics realistically looks like and hopefully convince them to go to college in physics. A public talk on dark matter is also scheduled to trigger the interest of both the public and the future generation of scientists.

Astroparticle physics, specifically, the search for dark matter, is currently one of the most attractive research areas. However, not many universities, and even less liberal arts colleges, offer a particle physics class at the undergraduate level. In addition, universities who offer a graduate program in astroparticle physics tend not to have an astroparticle physics class offered every year. All the topics of this summer school will be related to dark matter and will encompass both experiment and theory, in order to attract students in both experimental and theoretical physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DMSS: a Dark Matter Summer School was a week long summer school in astro-particle physics, and more specifically in the field of dark matter, that was geared towards junior graduate students, and senior undergraduates with research experience in the field of dark matter. The school was held at the University at Albany, SUNY, in Albany, NY, in the summer of 2018, and was composed of 14 lecturers and 36 participants. The school was highly successful, and feedback was unanimously positive. By the end of the school, the students had heared and learned from experts about both theory and experiments related to dark matter, including topics like large scale structure formation, supersymmetry, axions, neutrinos, direct and indirect experiments, colliders, and statistical methods used in rare event searches searches. The school had 3 components: lectures, discussions, and student presentations. The lectures were given by world experts from various prestigious universities amongst which MIT, Brown, and Princeton. There were three 90min lectures a day, each lecture was followed with a Q&A session and students were actively participating. Group discussions were scheduled every day where students were split in three groups, and each group could talk to a lecturer separately and discuss further on any topic of their choice. Finally, student presentations allowed the students to give a talk on their research in a low-key setting.

All the goals of the summer school were met:

1. students were given the opportunity to learn about their specific field of study, which is necessary as most universities do not offer a course in astro-particle physics, and in order to be good scientists, students should know about the bigger picture of their field of study

2. students were able to meet a lot of their peers, socialize and network, which is an extremely important part of research as it fosters future work collaborations

3. students were able to give oral presentations, for many of them, this was ideal as this was their first presentation, and was a lot less intimidating than a conference

4. this was the first diverse school in astro-particle physics, with 50% male - 50% female both at the lecturer and participant level. The diversity aspect was noted upon by both lecturers and participants as being incredibly appreciated, particularly with the female students who, for once, felt represented in their field of study
